div.p: A true Copy of Sir Henry Hides SPEECH ON THE SCAFFOLD, Immediately before his Execution before the EXCHANGE, on the 4th of March, 1650.
Taken in Short-hand from his mouth, BY JOHN HINDE.
LONDON: Printed by Peter Cole, at the Sign of the Printing-Pre≈øs in Cornhil by the Exchange. MDCL.

div.head: REader, Take notice, This Speech following is publi≈øhed in tho≈øe very words that the Gentleman delivered them; and though there be ≈øome abrupt breakings off, and other expre≈ø≈øions not ≈øo ≈ømooth as might have been, yet I could not with hone≈øty alter a word; and therefore have tyed my ≈øelf to his own Expre≈ø≈øions, that I may neither abu≈øe the World, or the dying man, or my ≈øelf.
div.p: THe Gentleman came in a Coach to the Scaffold, attended by the Lieutenant of the Tower, and the Sheriffs of London; and al≈øo in his company one of his Servants and Doctor Hide.

sp.speaker: Sir Henry Hide.
sp.p: I Am now come to put in practice the Chri≈øtian Profe≈ø≈øion; and as I owe a Death to Nature and Sin, now I pay it upon the ≈øcore of Grace.

sp.speaker: Dr. Hide.
sp.p: Ble≈ø≈øed be God that hath enabled you to it: God hath and will enable you.

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.stage: Looking round on the People, he ≈øaid,
sp.p: A populous City, God ble≈øs it, and grant they may live to his Grace. Then turning to his Man, he ≈øaid, John, I pray now though I have not been a good Ma≈øter to you, be you a good Servant, and accompany me with your Prayers, and help me both in Body and Minde. John, Have you my things about you, John?
sp.stage: Then ≈øtaying for his Servants, they being not on the Scaffold, he ≈øaid
sp.p: I had rather have my Servants then Strangers.
sp.stage: Then the Lieutenant of the Tower coming to him, he ≈øaid,
sp.p: Pray Sir rejoyce with me: I thank Almighty God I am brought hither to ≈øuffer for him.

sp.speaker: Lieut. of the Tower.
sp.p: I am glad you are ≈øo comforted: Gods will be fulfilled in all things.

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: If God call me to him, and I glorifie him, it is well: I ≈øeek onely the company of your Chri≈øtian Prayers.

sp.speaker: L. of the Tower.
sp.p: I ≈øhall not be wanting in that, God willing.

div.p: Then the Chyrurgion coming (but not his Kin≈øman, who was called for) he ≈øaid, My Kin≈øman is of no u≈øe, you may be u≈øeful about my Body. I hope Mr. Sheriff that you'll give order I may have a little more room here.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: And likewi≈øe for liberty of ≈øpeech; and that it ≈øhall plea≈øe you (for I am not acquainted with the Forms here of England) that I may ≈øpeak my one ≈øen≈øe (I am now going into the pre≈øence of Almighty God) a very little, without any di≈øturbance.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.p: Why Sir, you ≈øhall.

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: John, where is my Coffin?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: It is here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.p: Sir, it ≈øeems the≈øe men cannot be found.

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: But if Mr. Barret could be found.

div.p: After ≈øome ≈øtay, Mr. Barret being not found, the Sheriff ≈øpake to him, ≈øaying,

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.p: You have your liberty, you know your time.

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: Where is the place of ≈øtanding, that way or this way? (pointing towards the Exchange and the Poultrey.)

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.p: Which way you plea≈øe: you may ≈øtand which way you will, but that way you mu≈øt lie (pointing towards the Exchange.)

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: I am indifferent: It is not the way to Heaven where a man ≈øtands.

div.p: One brought word to him that there was no help to be had.

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: That is no hindrance to my felicity.

sp.speaker: Dr. Hide.
sp.p: God enable you, that you may finde that joy and comfort which is due to the glory of his Holy Name; he will not for≈øake you that have put your tru≈øt in him.

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: I will open my heart and my mouth with thank≈øgiving (if this Gentleman plea≈øe to give way.)
sp.stage: Then turning towards the Poultrey, he put of his Hat, and ≈øaid,

p.hi: Glory be to God on High, on Earth Peace, Good-will to men.

sp.p: CHri≈øtian People, I come hither to die, I am brought hither to die; and that I may die Chri≈øtian-like, I humbly be≈øeech the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of your Chri≈øtian Prayers, that by the benefit of them my pa≈ø≈øage may be the more ea≈øie; yet becau≈øe men in that condition, which it hath plea≈øed God to reduce me, carry more credit to their Speeches: In the di≈øcharge of my Duty towards God, I ≈øhall u≈øe a few words, and ≈øo di≈øpatch.

I pray all of you joyn with me to prai≈øe this Almighty God, to whom I de≈øire to render all hearty thanks; as for all his Mercies, ≈øo in particular for this, That he hath brought me hither: That whereas I owe a duty to Sin and to Nature, that now I can pay the account: A debt to Nature, I can pay it upon the account of Grace. And becau≈øe it is fit to render an account of that Hope that is in me, I ≈øhall tell you, to the prai≈øe of Almighty God, That I have been born and bred up in the Doctrine of the Church of England, I have no Negative Religion, beleeving to be ≈øaved by the onely Merits of my Saviour Je≈øus Chri≈øt (putting off his Hat) and what≈øoever el≈øe is profe≈øt in the Doctrine and Di≈øcipline of the Church of England, authorized by Law; humbly be≈øeeching Almighty God to re≈øtore unto this Church her Peace, Pro≈øperity and Patrimony, whereof I have been an Obedient and a Loving (however an unworthy) Son: And now both my Hope being confident, and my Faith perfected, there remains onely Chri≈øtian Charity; Charity we carry into Heaven, Charity on Earth, and that I leave, be≈øeeching all whom≈øoever I have offended (whether I have or no) to forgive me, as I from the
bottom of my Heart do them whom≈øoever; ble≈ø≈øing Almighty God for the happy Advantage he takes to bring me nearer to Heaven; ble≈ø≈øing Almighty God that he hath given me this Advantage, as he hath been merciful to me before the Foundation of the World, in my Saviour, ≈øo that now he hath in Mercy honored me, with a ≈øuffering for his Name, in obedience to his Commandment.

On this day ≈øeven-night I was ≈øummoned before that Ju≈øtice, which condemned me on Friday la≈øt, prai≈øed be Almighty God, that by this way he hath brought me the nearer to Him≈øelf (putting off his Hat) My Charge I pre≈øume is publike, as my Puni≈øhment is vi≈øible: if there have been any thing in the Management of my part, being unskilful, having di≈øcontinued my own Countrey many years, I ≈øhall be≈øeech the Chri≈øtian Charity of all you my beloved Countreymen, to impute it unto the right part, The ignorance that is in this skilful way of managing: It was objected unto me there, That I had a vanity of delighting to ≈øpeak in ≈øtrange Tongues. I was be≈øt skill'd in the Italian (but free from that vanity I thank Almighty God) and therefore I would in defence of my life (if it had been the Cu≈øtom here, or the Judges favor) have u≈øed that Language.

It was objected, That I did not ≈øo freely as a through-paced Cavalier, own my Ma≈øter: I was told ≈øince I came into England (for other skill I have not in your Laws) that a legal Denial in Law might be tolerable; I hope I did not exceed the Bounds of that in anything, for God forbid that I ≈øhould be a≈øhamed of ≈øerving ≈øo good, ≈øo pious, ≈øo ju≈øt a Ma≈øter (putting off his hat) for that therein I rejoyce, and I humbly be≈øeech
Almighty God, to fill my heart and my tongue, and all that hear me this day, with thankfulne≈øs for it.

As to the Bu≈øine≈øs, that another Con≈øtruction had been made and believed here, then what was there, the Righteous God knoweth it; if any weakne≈øs is in the management, tho≈øe were mine: I was ≈øent to ≈øerve and protect, not to injure any, and as God acquits me of the intention in matter of Fact, as having done any maner of evil that way, however here under≈øtood, ble≈ø≈øed be his holy Name, (putting off his hat) ≈øo tho≈øe Gentlemen of the Turky Company, if they would but ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øider, for they know it very well, the impo≈ø≈øibility of my doing them any maner of harm. Whereas that of the Emba≈ø≈øie objected again≈øt me, that my Ma≈øter never honored me withal, I was never worthy of it, I was his Me≈ø≈øenger an Internuncio, for the Con≈øervation onely of his good Subjects, of all the Merchants, untill ≈øuch time as he could confirm that Gentleman now Re≈øident, or to ≈øend any other; and they them≈øelves know that there was impo≈ø≈øibility in me (as I ble≈øs God there was an innocency in me) unto any ≈øuch intention to do them any harm; for my Ma≈øters Commands were point-blank the contrary; I was onely ≈øent for their good, as I never owned the Title, ≈øo the very Letters them≈øelves ≈øpeaking no other: I never did ≈øo much as think of any maner of Addre≈øs unto the Grand Seignior, but gave him the Letter from my Ma≈øter; the re≈øt of the Engli≈øh Nation that were there pre≈øent, may, when they plea≈øe, a≈ø≈øert ≈øo much. This I would in≈øert, that tho≈øe Gentlemen, as they have been lo≈øers by the mi≈øcarriages of others, may now have no breach of their Charity with me; but if it be, as it ≈øeems it is now in this Countrey,
a Sin to be Loyal, I hope my God hath forgiven that, when it is upon harmle≈øs Imployment, not invading any, according to his ju≈øt Ma≈øters Order; for indeed I have been always bred up in that Religion, my Allegiance hath been incorporated into my Religion, and I have thought it a great part of the ≈øervice due from me to Almighty God, to ≈øerve the King (putting off his hat.) I need not make any Apology for any thing in relation to the pre≈øent things in England, for were I (as I ≈øpake before my Judges) were I as evil as my Sentence hath here made me black, it were impo≈ø≈øible for me to have prejudiced any body in England, or to England belonging, in that imployment; but I ble≈øs God for his infinite Mercy in Je≈øus Chri≈øt (putting off his hat) who hath brought me home to him here in this way, it was the be≈øt Phy≈øick for the curing of my Soul, and tho≈øe that have done it, have no more power then that of my body. I leave nothing behinde me, but that I am willing to part withal; all that I am going to, is de≈øireable: And that you may all know that Almighty God hath totally wrought in me a total Denial of my ≈øelf, and that there is that perfect Reformation of me within, and of my own corruptions by the ble≈ø≈øed A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his holy Spirit, I de≈øire Almighty God in the abundance of the bowels of his Mercy in Je≈øus Chri≈øt, not onely to forgive every Enemy, (if any ≈øuch be in the world, here or where≈øoever) but to bring him into his bo≈øom ≈øo much good and particular comfort, as he may at any time, whether the Cau≈øe were ju≈øt or unju≈øt, have wi≈øhed me any maner of evil, for I take him to be the happy In≈øtrument of bringing me to Heaven. It is tedious, but I have an inward comfort, I ble≈øs Almighty God: (pray Gentlemen
give leave, ≈øpeaking to ≈øome that pre≈øt upon him) I ≈øhould never do it but to give ≈øatisfaction to all charitable Hearts. I have been trouble≈øom.

p.hi: You have your liberty to ≈øpeak more, if you plea≈øe.

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p:
But as to that part, Mr. Sheriff, that did concern the Denial (as it was affirmed by Ma≈øter Attorney General) of my Ma≈øters imployment, Truly landing at Whitehall I told that Councel, there was ju≈øt Commi≈ø≈øions to an old Officer by the ble≈ø≈øing of God, I have by me, and I have other good things that God hath ble≈ø≈øed me withal, more then all the good Chri≈øtians in the world, that are not the Grand Seignior's Slaves; and we that are Merchants abroad, we allow our ≈øelves any ≈øufferance that may induce to our own ≈øafety, inlargement of Trade, or pre≈øervation of what is ours. Why I had by the grace of my gracious Ma≈øter a confirmation of my old Commi≈ø≈øion of Con≈øulage in Greece; but as to the Emba≈ø≈øie, no more then my Credential Letters did ≈øpeak, nor no more then that I attempted, an Internuncio they call it in tho≈øe places, which is a Me≈ø≈øenger between the one and the other King. They both unhappily dyed of ≈øeveral deaths, and both violent too; and it is a cu≈øtom not unknown to you, Ma≈øter Sheriff, and other Gentlemen that practice in the world, that Princes of cour≈øe, for the continuation of Amity, do ≈øend Me≈ø≈øengers where there is peace, that the Tran≈øaction of tho≈øe publike Expre≈ø≈øions of recipocrol Affections may be performed; but for Emba≈ø≈øie, God forbid I ≈øhould own it, I never had it, however they have u≈øed it as the happy means to bring me to God this day. I be≈øeech God in the bowels of my Saviour, to forgive
tho≈øe people that have done it, as I owe them no harm, ≈øo God pay them home with all the good of this, and an everla≈øting Life.
As for Power, I have been long ab≈øent here in England, I meddle with none: Sufficient for me is Gods Grace to the Salvation of my Soul.

I have been always fearful of offending Almighty God, according to the Grace he hath given me: But to learn a New-Religion, and New-Ways (that I mu≈øt ≈øay Ma≈øter Sheriff to you, and all others that hear me) I cannot di≈øpence with my Con≈øcience to give offence to Almighty God. I am now (if it may be with your Commi≈ø≈øion, Ma≈øter Sheriff) to pour out my Soul to Almighty God in two or three words (the place is ≈øtraitned.) If I knew wherein to give any ≈øatisfaction to any thing what≈øoever, wherein I have offended or no, I am here in the fear of God to do it. I forgive with all my Soul, and my forgivene≈øs is clear, as I am now going to receive Happine≈øs at the hand of my Saviour: But if I thought it were ≈øati≈øfaction to Sir Thomas Bendi≈øh, and all the Company, or any who may think they have offended me, I am come Ma≈øter Sheriff to pay that Obedience willingly; that Debt I owe to Nature, to pay it upon the ≈øcore of a Subject; becau≈øe Con≈øcience within me, tells-me not, that for the intentions of ≈øerving my Prince, that I could de≈øerve ≈øuch a Death, though Ten thou≈øand times more other ways.

p.hi: There was ≈øome ≈øu≈øpition that you might impart the way you were upon to ≈øome of tho≈øe Servants that were with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Henry Hide.
sp.p:
I humbly thank you for remembring me of it, and if any be here of the Turky Company
this day, or any Friend of theirs, I ≈øhall de≈øire them from a dying Man, to take this truth, That neither my Brother, my innocent Brother that is with me, nor other Gentlemen with me in my company, have contributed any thing to their di≈øturbance; it was my own bu≈øine≈øs, what≈øoever hath been done, that hath been to evil, or lo≈øs, though I deny both of them in my Intentions: I come not here to accu≈øe any man, nor to excu≈øe my ≈øelf, but to prai≈øe God for all his deliverances; yet I know I ≈øhall do God a great deal of Service, and them a great deal of Ju≈øtice, in not involving any of my company in any thing of mi≈øchief. I cannot an≈øwer Objections; I finde a man may be in Turky, or any place, all the World over, where they will give that Language which they hold fitting; but this is beneath me. Ble≈ø≈øed be Almighty God, that hath called me to the Knowledge of him, and this ready Obedience which I pay, and merciful accepting of my Saviour, and patient Death: And I be≈øeech you all, whatever you are, That you will accompany me with your Prayers, whereby my Soul may be a≈ø≈øi≈øted within me, in that pa≈ø≈øage to my Saviour whither I am going. I am weak of Body; I have di≈øcontinued long from the Kingdom; I am unacquainted with new Forms; I have de≈øired to ≈øerve God according to his Commandments after the Old way: I have begged mercy of God for all my offences to him; and I have had my pardon ≈øealed from Heaven by the Blood of my Saviour: I beg pardon of all who≈øoever, whether I have offended them, or no: I truly forgive them, and have be≈øought Almighty God to pour his ble≈ø≈øings upon them. I accu≈øe no man, I finde fault, nor quarrel with no man; neither
with the per≈øons that were the occa≈øions, they were but the In≈øtruments; neither at the per≈øons condemning. I accept thankfully the Sentence of Death upon my ≈øelf; and I be≈øeech Almighty God, that I may be the la≈øt that may ≈øuffer upon this ≈øcore, or upon any other.

Ma≈øter Sheriff, If there be any thing wherein I can give any other ≈øatisfaction to any Chri≈øtian what≈øoever, in any kinde, as I ≈øpake in general, I ble≈øs Almighty God from my own Heart, now ≈øo a≈ø≈øi≈øted, by the e≈øpecial Operation, and Motions, and Dictates of the Holy Gho≈øt: if I can know any thing, wherein, or how to be now in my dying (not having ≈øerved God ≈øo well in my life) ≈øerviceable to the Church of God, of Chri≈øt, and the full ≈øatisfaction of any what≈øoever, I am here ready: I am unacqainted, but in my exta≈øies to Heaven, there is that Glory I am going to. I be≈øeech Almighty God, that he will give me Grace to ble≈øs his holy Name; as for all, as for Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and in him all things, ≈øo particularly for this, That he hath thought me worthy to bring me hither for my Faithfulne≈øs to my Ma≈øter, for doing what I was commanded by my Ma≈øter, that is the mo≈øt Pious, and mo≈øt Ju≈øt Prince in all the World. My Ma≈øter hath ≈øuffered bitterly in England; and if there be any failing in his Service, the fault is onely mine. God knows I have done nothing in the bu≈øine≈øs, but by the in≈øtance of the Merchants; I delivered my Letters, and there they lie: To other things I am a Stranger. I hope that God will give me the Grace of Per≈øeverance in that Chri≈øtian Religion; in that Loyalty to my Prince; in that Love to all the World, that now (being to give up my Account to
him, that) I may with comfort be received in the Arms of his Mercy.

If there be any thing, Ma≈øter Sheriff, that I may give ≈øatisfaction in, I am ready to do it according to the poor Talent I have. I will receive my puni≈øhment in the way God hath prepared for me; and many ways I have been taken up. Truly I am bound to all that ≈øee me, and many thou≈øands more ≈øince I came into England, not an uncivil look (we had ≈øtrange reports abroad) not an uncivil look from any: God repay them all, and return them from the Throne of his Grace into their own bo≈øoms. And God in particular ble≈øs that Honorable Lady, who was the occa≈øion of the coming of my Lords Grace of Armagh, with the Confirmation of tho≈øe glorious and eternal Me≈ø≈øages of Comfort which now I am going to enjoy: being thankful to all tho≈øe that know me, and know me not; for ≈øince I am come hither, whereas I might have received prejudice in re≈øpect to my Loyalty (which is not the way, now) I have from them all received courte≈øie, the Lord repay them. I thank God I am otherwi≈øe bred, and my Allegiance hath been incorporated, imbodied into my Religion; and be≈øides the great de≈øires of other Gentlemen, that I might not go out of the world, but that the world might ≈øee that the grace of God hath had a perfect Reformation in me, and a willing and thankful Submi≈ø≈øion to his Will, therefore I repent me not of it; but I be≈øeech Almighty God to ble≈øs and pro≈øper all people what≈øoever that to this Kingdom belong. As my Speech is imperfect, ≈øo is my Health. I have forced my ≈øelf in this Di≈øcour≈øe to give that ≈øatisfaction which I could. And I be≈øeech you, Mr. Sheriff,
if you can hear of any Gentlemen that are wronged, what I offer here, I am to an≈øwer it; and I be≈øeech you joyn with me in your Chri≈øtian Prayers, that I may have a pa≈ø≈øage whither I am now going to give an account, not onely of every deed, but of every word.

div.p: Then turning to his Man, he ≈øaid,

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: John, which is the Executioner?

div.p: The Executioner being brought to him, he ≈øaid,

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: Hone≈øt Friend, I have no quarrel with you, you are the welcom In≈øtrument, do your work; onely let me ≈øee the place, that I may fit my ≈øelf, for I have an infirm body.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.p: You ≈øhall when you have prayed; if you plea≈øe to pray fir≈øt.

sp.speaker: Sir H. Hide.
sp.p: I de≈øire to ≈øee the Block, I can pray afterwards. Here Mr. Executioner is that Money that is left; here is Four pounds for you.
